About Us

Every content creator deserves peace of mind. That's why we have created the YouTube audio copyright checker— a tool that lets you check your audio rights within seconds.

The idea behind our license checker was born out of a simple yet pressing concern—how do you know if a song is copyrighted on YouTube before it's too late? Many creators have faced the frustration of seeing their hard work flagged because of copyright issues.

Our founders, who are creative professionals themselves, faced these problems firsthand. That's how we saw a need for a tool that could help content creators avoid these pitfalls.

Who We Are?

We are a team of passionate musicians and tech geeks with the same aim: to make the content creation process as stress-free as possible. Our shared love for creativity led us to develop a tool that clarifies music licensing for creators worldwide.

It wasn't easy. We have spent years creating the tool to make sure it delivers the accuracy that creators deserve. Our team has set up complex algorithms that can scan extensive databases within seconds. The interface was made as simple as possible so that even beginners can use it without any challenges.

But that wasn't enough. We wanted to make sure that this tool was accessible to everyone, especially those creators who may not have the resources to pay for expensive software. That's why we decided to offer our copyright music checker completely free of cost. Not even ads were placed so as to keep the tool as fast and user-friendly as possible. This is possible thanks to TubePilot, which offered their API free of charge.

As we continue to grow, our commitment remains steadfast: to improve our services based on your feedback. Try out our YouTube audio copyright checker now!

Our Mission

To give content creators the confidence that their hard work is protected, using a free and easy-to-use tool.

Our Vision

We aim to create a safe space where everyone can focus on creating their craft without worrying about copyright restrictions and protect the rights of concerned license owners.

Why You Must Check Copyright?

Copyright checks are a must for content creators, especially on platforms like YouTube, where using copyrighted material without permission can even lead to account bans. Check out some reasons to do it every time before you upload a video:

Protecting Your Revenue

Using copyrighted music without permission can lead to demonetization of your videos. No matter how good the video performs, the entire ad revenue goes to the copyright holder, not you. Therefore, it is always better to check the copyright of a video before uploading to make sure that the revenue from it remains in your pocket.

Legal Protection

What if, instead of earning from your video, you end up having to pay to use it? Well, if a copyright holder decides to take action against unauthorized use of their work, it can lead to costly legal settlements. Checking copyrights can protect you legally.

Avoid Copyright Strikes

If you use copyrighted music without permission, YouTube’s Content ID system can automatically detect it and issue a strike. Too many strikes can lead to your videos being removed. After three strikes, your entire channel could be taken down. Our YouTube song copyright checker can prevent this by flagging copyrighted material before you upload it.

Maintain Creative Control

When you use copyrighted music, you lose control over the video. Copyright holders can impose restrictions that limit your ability to distribute and use it. So, to be on the safe side, verify whether you have complete ownership over the audio through a YouTube audio copyright checker.

Save Your Channel Performance

YouTube algorithms often classify channels that repeatedly publish copyright material and punish them. It may take your video down from recommendations and even restrict your account. This affects not just the copyrighted content but all your videos. As a result, your visibility may fall all of a sudden. The only way to stay out of this is through regular copyright checks.

Copyright protection is not just for big companies. In fact, our YouTube music copyright checker is beneficial for anyone who wants to publish videos on platforms like YouTube. Here are some sects that may find it most useful:

Content Creators

Platforms like YouTube have an automated content ID system that lets them quickly detect copyrighted music. Our tool lets creators check their music beforehand to ensure it’s safe for monetization.

Music Producers

Music production companies that upload the original content must check their work doesn't unintentionally include copyrighted elements. Otherwise, it may lead to legal issues. With our tool, you can ensure that you are using copyright-free YouTube music.

Vloggers and Podcasters

Both vloggers and podcasters often use soundtracks in the background to make the video more engaging. It’s easy to accidentally include copyrighted music without realizing it. Our YouTube song copyright checker allows them to verify the copyright status of tracks quickly.

Educational Institutions

Like vloggers, trainers tend to add music to improve engagement. However, note that even non-profit education institutions are not exempt from copyright laws. We can help them verify that their channel remains safe from copyright strikes.

Gaming Streamers

Some games use licensed tracks that could trigger Content ID matches. Using our YouTube audio copyright checker can help you identify potential issues before they cost you your hard-earned views or, worse, your channel.

Consequences of Copyright Infringement

Copyright issues are emerging as a big headache for content creators. Even a small infringement could lead to severe consequences. Some of the main impacts are as below:

Copyright Strikes And Bans

YouTube has a strong built-in mechanism, such as a content ID system, to catch copyright issues on the spot. If detected, the consequences could be nasty. Have a look at what you can expect after each detection:
  • First strike: You will receive a warning and possibly lose some features like live streaming for a limited time.
  • Second strike: More serious penalties, such as a temporary ban from uploading new content, can be applied.
  • Third Strike: Your YouTube account could be permanently banned, and all your videos may be taken down.

Remember, if banned, recovering your account is nearly impossible. All the hard work that you have put in to build an organic audience base will be lost all of a sudden.

Loss of Monetization

In case you already have monetization, copyright infringements can lead to loss of revenue. Either the revenue from it will go to the original copyright holder or YouTube may disable it. In the worst cases, the platform may disable monetization for your entire channel.

Legal Penalties

On top of the revenue loss, you may even have to pay a large sum out of your pocket. For content creators who rely on their income from platforms like YouTube, these fines can be devastating and may lead to bankruptcy in severe cases.

Reputation Hit

Frequent copyright strikes may hurt your brand reputation. Your audience may see you as someone who doesn’t respect intellectual property and may even unsubscribe. Brands and sponsors may hesitate to collaborate with you, fearing that their campaigns could be compromised by takedowns.

Reduced Performance in Search Algorithms

Sometimes, the impact of copyright infringement may be implicit. YouTube algorithms naturally take your content away from recommendations if your channel is frequently facing copyright issues. As a result of reduced visibility, your videos will get fewer views and lower engagement.

How To Check If A Song Is Copyrighted?

There are several methods to check if a specific song is copyrighted or not. Here are the three most prominent ways:

Use YouTube Content ID

One of the simplest methods to check whether an audio track is safe or not is to post it. Yes, that’s right! You can upload your video with the song as a private or unlisted video. As soon as the uploading is completed, YouTube will run its automated Content ID checks against its database of copyrighted tracks. Within seconds, you will get notified of any copyright claims through YouTube Studio.

The entire process happens quickly but does not guarantee the safety of your video because not all songs are registered in YouTube’s Content ID database. Copyright owners, who have not submitted it for ID verification, can still claim the rights later.

Check The Descriptions

The simplest step you can take when using external music is to check the descriptions and details of the video. Many artists include copyright information in the descriptions of their music videos on YouTube. Some may include it either at the beginning or end of the video with a ‘©’ symbol. However, such prior notices may not always be present.

YouTube Audio Copyright Checker

The most fool-proof method to verify song copyrights is our YouTube music copyright checker tool. Check out how to use our tool:
  • Copy The Link: First of all, copy the link to the YouTube video that you want to check.
  • Visit the Website: Go to our website and paste the link into the text box. Otherwise, you can just enter the video's name. Now, click the search button.
  • View The Results: Within seconds, our tool will display whether it is safe to use the video along with a report.

Alternatives To Copyrighted Music

Using copyrighted music can cause major headaches for content creators, especially on platforms like YouTube. But don't worry—there are plenty of great alternatives to copyright-protected music that allow you to add music to your videos without risking strikes or penalties. Here are the best options to consider:

Royalty-Free Music

Royalty-free music is a popular option that allows you to pay once (or not at all, depending on the source) and use the music in your videos without worrying about copyright issues. There are many websites where you can find a wide variety of royalty-free tracks. Some of the prominent ones are Free Music Archiver, Epidemic Sound, Artlist, and ccMixter. You can even pick copyright-free YouTube music videos from our gallery section.

Creative Commons Music

If you are working on a tight budget, try out audio tracks with Creative Commons licenses. It lets artists share their music while giving others permission to use it under certain conditions.

It is free and legal. But there’s a catch. You may need to give attribution. Luckily, some even allow free use with no strings attached. Make sure to check the specific license to see what’s required.

Use Your Own Music

The safest option is absolutely the creation of your own music. Consider renting a studio and creating audio tracks in bulk for videos over the next few months. Perhaps, you can even collaborate with upcoming artists who are looking for exposure. Offer to feature them in exchange for music rights. It’s a win-win situation, right?

YouTube Audio Library

In case all three options do not work for you, come to YouTube. The platform has an extensive audio library with thousands of tracks that you can use safely. You can search the library by mood, genre, or track name. All you need is a YouTube account.

Best Practices For Using Music Legally

Music can bring life to your video. But it's important to do it the right way to avoid copyright issues. Here are some best practices to ensure you're using music legally:

Check If A Song is Copyrighted

Before using any music– no matter how short it is – check if it is copyrighted. Never assume that a song isn’t copyrighted just because it’s popular or widely shared. First of all, review the descriptions and video to know if there’s any copyright marks. Then, check using our YouTube audio copyright checker or through the YouTube content ID system directly. It’s not that time-consuming, considering the consequences of copyright infringement.

Use Royalty-Free Music

The most practical approach to staying safe from copyright issues is the usage of royalty-free music. These tracks come with licenses that allow you to use the music without the risk of copyright claims. You have two options:
  1. Royalty-free music: You just need to pay a one-time fee to use the music safely in your content. YouTube gives you the option to buy a license for music from their platform.
  2. Copyright-free YouTube music: As the name suggests, it refers to music tracks that are not protected by copyright law. You can use them freely as much as you want.
Platforms like the YouTube Audio Library offer a large selection of copyright-free and royalty-free tracks that are safe to use on the platform.

Read The License Agreement Carefully

A royalty-free or Creative Commons License doesn’t mean that you can sit back and relax. Some licenses may have specific requirements, such as giving credit to the artist. Here are the key points to look at in a license agreement:

  1. Attribution requirements: Some songs may require you to give credit to the artist in the video description.
  2. Commercial use: Ensure the license allows you to use the music for commercial purposes if you're monetizing your videos.
  3. Modifications: Check if you're allowed to remix or modify the track in any way.

For extra safety, always keep a copy of the license agreement or proof of purchase, especially if you’re using royalty-free music. This can protect you if a claim is ever made.

Use Licensed Music For Commercial Usage

The fact is that most royalty-free tracks won’t allow commercial usage. You may need to purchase a license for it. Even though it is expensive, obtaining the copyright holder’s permission ensures that you are safe.

Some websites offer easy licensing for commercial tracks, such as AudioJungle. They simplify the process of acquiring legal rights to popular songs.

Avoid Common Copyright Pitfalls

There are several misconceptions that can lead content creators into legal trouble. Here are some things to avoid:

  1. Do not rely on short clips: Many creators think that using just a few seconds of a song won’t trigger copyright claims. However, YouTube’s Content ID system is highly advanced and can detect even short snippets of copyrighted music.
  2. Don’t assume ‘fair use’ applies: Fair use is a legal defense that only applies in specific cases, such as commentary, criticism, or parody. Just because you’re using a song for educational purposes doesn’t mean you’re protected.
  3. Be cautious with remixes and covers: Even if you’re adding your own creativity to a song for a remix, it’s still based on copyrighted material. You may need to obtain permission from the original artist.

Stay Updated

Copyright laws change from time to time. So, you must stay informed about the current regulation, both legally and from the side of platforms like YouTube.

Frequently Asked Questions

Find answers to common questions about our music copyright checker and gallery.

How to check if a song is copyrighted on YouTube?

+

Go to our website. Paste the link or enter the name of the song that you want to check. Within seconds, our YouTube Music Copyright Checker displays whether it is safe to use or not.

What happens if a song is copyrighted?

+

If a song is copyrighted, you cannot use it without permission from the copyright holder. Using them may result in suspensions or even bans from platforms like YouTube. On top of that, the copyright holder can sue for a hefty amount.

Can I use copyrighted music if I give credit?

+

No. Giving credit does not always protect you from copyright claims. Even if you mention the artist, YouTube’s copyright system may flag your video. You must purchase the license to use the music from the original copyright holder.

Is all music on YouTube copyrighted?

+

Not all music on YouTube is copyrighted! Many creators offer their music under Creative Commons licenses or provide royalty-free options. It is always better to check the descriptions and with third-party tools like ours to verify the copyright status of music before using them.

What types of music are considered copyright-free?

+

Well, it includes anything without a copyright license. You can count on tracks that are in the public domain, those licensed under Creative Commons, and royalty-free music (those without paying ongoing fees).

How can I use copyright-free YouTube music?

+

There are many ways to create or find copyright-free YouTube music. You can use the YouTube audio library or any external websites, like our gallery of copyright free music, to get access to music that you can use. You can even create royalty-free music on your own without any cost and experience by using AI tools.

How accurate is your copyright checker?

+

Our tool offers 95% accuracy by fetching real-time data from YouTube's database. Even though we try to correctly inform about the copyright status of the music, we do not guarantee the accuracy.

What should I do if my video gets a copyright claim?

+

Paste the link to it in our tool and see if the music used is indeed copyrighted. In case it is still flagged, consider removing the track or replacing it with one that’s copyright-free from our gallery. If you believe it is wrongly flagged, you can submit a copyright removal request.
